Sears Home AdvantageAppointment Lookup802-552-4364Schedule NowRepairHome WarrantyTune-Up & MaintainHVACShop PartsResourcesSears LogoRepairAmana+Oven{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"BreadcrumbList","itemListElement":[{"@type":"ListItem","position":1,"item":"https://www.searshomeservices.com/repair","name":"Repair"},{"@type":"ListItem","position":2,"item":"https://www.searshomeservices.com/repair/amana","name":"Amana"},{"@type":"ListItem","position":3,"item":"https://www.searshomeservices.com/repair/oven-repair-service","name":"Oven"}]}Amana Oven RepairWe're in your neighborhood, and we'll fix it no matter where you bought it.Schedule service your waySchedule NowCall(802) 552-4364ChatWill you be using repair benefits from a Sears or other warranty plan?Amana Oven Repair GuideRegardless of the type of Amana oven you have, the appliance repair experts at Sears Home Services can perform quality repairs for problems big or small. A service call involves diagnosing the appliance's malfunction and making repairs quickly. A repair technician can also recommend routine maintenance to extend your oven's life.
We work on Amana ovens all the time. While mostly a reliable appliance, your oven can eventually break at any time.
After thousands of service visits, we've identified several issues that tend to frustrate homeowners most.
Oven Not Heating Up
Turn the oven on and wait. And wait. And nothing happens. No heat. This happens with Amanas more than you'd think. It’s usually caused by a few common culprits.

The igniter gets weak over time. It's supposed to glow hot enough to open the gas valve, but after a few years they just can't get hot enough anymore. You might see it glowing orange but the burner never lights. Or sometimes it takes forever to light, way longer than it should. Igniters aren't cheap parts, but they're the most common thing to fail on gas Amana ovens.
Electric models have different problems. The bake element might be burned out. Look for holes or blisters in the element, or spots where it's clearly broken. They don't always show obvious damage though. Sometimes they look fine but are dead inside. Like some people I've worked with over the years.
Broken wires happen too. The oven gets hot, then cold, over and over for years. Wires get brittle. Connections work loose. One bad connection anywhere in the circuit and the whole oven won't heat.

Control Board Problems
Control boards go bad in the newer electronic models. Everything looks normal on the display, but no command ever reaches the heating elements. These boards hate power surges. One good lightning storm and they're fried. Replacing them isn't a simple job. They cost a fair bit too, sometimes almost half what a new oven would run you.
Schedule wall oven repair when the control won’t work on your Amana oven.
Temperature All Wrong
We had a customer last month, said his cookies always burned even when he set the temperature real low. It turns out his Amana oven was running about 75 degrees hotter than what the control was set to. Temperature issues are frustrating.
The temperature sensor goes out of calibration. It's just a little probe sticking into the back of the oven cavity. It gets covered in grease and gunk over time. Sometimes it gets bent or damaged when people clean. If it's not in the right position or damaged, you get bad readings.
Loose connections to the sensor cause temperature swings too. The computer thinks the oven is colder than it really is because it's getting intermittent readings. So it overshoots the temp you wanted.
The thermostat in older models gets sticky. Mechanical parts wear out. They don't cycle on and off like they should. Your oven just keeps getting hotter and hotter. That’s not good for that delicate pastry recipe.
Schedule appliance repair service whenever you run into heating problems with your Amana oven.
The Door Won't Close Right
Oven doors take abuse over their life. Slammed shut. Kids hanging on them. Heavy roasting pans bumping into them. Eventually they get out of whack.
Hinges wear out or bend. The door doesn't sit flush anymore. Heat escapes around the edges. Your kitchen gets hot while your food doesn't. Sometimes you can adjust the hinges a bit, but usually they need replacement when they get bad.
Door springs weaken too. The door might drop suddenly instead of closing gently. Those springs help support the weight of the door. When they get weak, the hinges take more stress than they were designed for. Leads to more problems down the road.
The gasket around the door gets torn or compressed. Doesn't make a good seal anymore. Heat leaks out. Makes the oven work harder and your food take longer to cook. Gaskets can be replaced, but getting the old adhesive off is a pain in the neck.
Self-Cleaning Problems
Self-cleaning sounds great on paper. In practice, it's where a lot of problems start. Amanas are no exception.

The extreme heat during cleaning kills electronic parts. Control boards, switches, and wiring take a beating when the oven gets that hot. Sometimes they work fine for years, then you run self-clean once and something dies. That’s just the way it goes.
Door locks stick after cleaning. The lock is supposed to release when the oven cools down. Sometimes the mechanism gets gummed up or bent and the door stays locked. Not ideal when your oven is suddenly a vault you can't open.
Heating elements give up during the clean cycle. All that extra heat pushes them past their breaking point, especially if they were already getting weak. Many repair guys will tell you to never use self-clean. Just wipe the oven out regular instead.

Burners Acting Up
Cooktop burners have their own sets of problems, different ones for gas and electric models.
Gas burners clog up with food spills. The little holes get blocked and you see uneven flames or yellow tips instead of blue. Poking them clean with a pin helps sometimes, but you’ve got to be careful not to enlarge the holes.
Spark igniters fail or get dirty. You hear them clicking but the burner won't light. Or they don't click at all. Food boils over and gums up the igniter. Clean them with a toothbrush and some alcohol. Beats replacing them.
Electric coils have it rough. Stuff spills on them constantly. They're built to take it, but connections corrode over time. The burner receptacles where they plug in get burned or bent. Sometimes a burner works when you jiggle it just right, but that's a fire hazard waiting to happen.
Strange Noises
Amana ovens make all kinds of weird sounds when they're having trouble. Different noises mean different problems.
Buzzing or humming usually points to something electrical. Relay switches buzz when they're not making good contact. The transformer hums louder than it should when it's going bad. Bad news either way.
Clicking repeatedly, not just when starting up, means a relay or switch is cycling on and off too fast. It could be a bad connection or failing part.
Grinding noises from the convection fan mean the bearings are shot. Or something's come loose and is hitting the fan blade. Shut it off until it's fixed or you'll have a bigger problem.
Booming when a gas oven ignites means gas built up before lighting. The igniter's weak or the gas flow needs adjustment. Not something to ignore - it can get dangerous.
Digital Display Dead
The display screen just dies on some models. It goes completely blank or shows gibberish.

Power glitches kill these displays sometimes. Try resetting the control board. Unplug the oven shut off the house circuit breaker for a few minutes. Restore power and see if the oven works. This simple fix sometimes works.
Ribbon cables work loose. They connect the display to the control board. Heat and time make them brittle or they just vibrate loose. Getting to them means taking apart the control panel. Not difficult but lots of small screws to keep track of.
Water damage happens too. Steam from cooking gets into places it shouldn't. Condensation builds up inside the control panel. Eventually shorts something out. Doesn't help that many kitchens put the oven below the cooktop where all the steam rises past the controls.

When To Call For Service
Some Amana oven issues you can handle yourself. Cleaning burners, replacing light bulbs, maybe even changing the oven gasket if you're handy. Keep your manual handy. Save yourself a service call when it's something simple.
But for anything involving gas, electricity, or major disassembly, that's when calling us makes sense. Our techs have seen every Amana problem there is. Keeping your family safe matters more than saving a few bucks trying to fix a gas valve yourself.
We stock parts for all the common Amana problems. Can usually fix things in one visit. And we guarantee our work. No crossing your fingers hoping you fixed it right.
Give us a call when your Amana needs professional attention. We'll get your kitchen back to normal without the headache. evenly and often more quickly than a traditional oven.What is a Thermocouple?A thermocouple is a sensor used for measuring temperature, consisting of two different metal wires joined at one end, which generate a voltage proportional to temperature changes.What is an Oven Bag?An oven bag is a heat-resistant, nylon or polyester bag designed for cooking a wide variety of foods in the oven, ensuring moist and flavorful meals by trapping moisture and flavor inside.What is an Oven Rack?An oven rack is a removable shelving unit inside an oven that holds cookware, allowing air to circulate around the RepairAmana+Oven{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"BreadcrumbList","itemListElement":[{"@type":"ListItem","position":1,"item":"https://www.searshomeservices.com/repair","name":"Repair"},{"@type":"ListItem","position":2,"item":"https://www.searshomeservices.com/repair/amana","name":"Amana"},{"@type":"ListItem","position":3,"item":"https://www.searshomeservices.com/repair/oven-repair-service","name":"Oven"}]}Amana Oven RepairWe're in your neighborhood, and we'll fix it no matter where you bought it.Schedule service your waySchedule NowCall(802) 552-4364ChatWill you be using repair benefits from a Sears or other warranty plan?Amana Oven Repair GuideRegardless of the type of Amana oven you have, the appliance repair experts at Sears Home Services can perform quality repairs for problems big or small. A service call involves diagnosing the appliance's malfunction and making repairs quickly. A repair technician can also recommend routine maintenance to extend your oven's life.
We work on Amana ovens all the time. While mostly a reliable appliance, your oven can eventually break at any time.
After thousands of service visits, we've identified several issues that tend to frustrate homeowners most.
Oven Not Heating Up
Turn the oven on and wait. And wait. And nothing happens. No heat. This happens with Amanas more than you'd think. It’s usually caused by a few common culprits.

The igniter gets weak over time. It's supposed to glow hot enough to open the gas valve, but after a few years they just can't get hot enough anymore. You might see it glowing orange but the burner never lights. Or sometimes it takes forever to light, way longer than it should. Igniters aren't cheap parts, but they're the most common thing to fail on gas Amana ovens.
Electric models have different problems. The bake element might be burned out. Look for holes or blisters in the element, or spots where it's clearly broken. They don't always show obvious damage though. Sometimes they look fine but are dead inside. Like some people I've worked with over the years.
Broken wires happen too. The oven gets hot, then cold, over and over for years. Wires get brittle. Connections work loose. One bad connection anywhere in the circuit and the whole oven won't heat.

Control Board Problems
Control boards go bad in the newer electronic models. Everything looks normal on the display, but no command ever reaches the heating elements. These boards hate power surges. One good lightning storm and they're fried. Replacing them isn't a simple job. They cost a fair bit too, sometimes almost half what a new oven would run you.
Schedule wall oven repair when the control won’t work on your Amana oven.
Temperature All Wrong
We had a customer last month, said his cookies always burned even when he set the temperature real low. It turns out his Amana oven was running about 75 degrees hotter than what the control was set to. Temperature issues are frustrating.
The temperature sensor goes out of calibration. It's just a little probe sticking into the back of the oven cavity. It gets covered in grease and gunk over time. Sometimes it gets bent or damaged when people clean. If it's not in the right position or damaged, you get bad readings.
Loose connections to the sensor cause temperature swings too. The computer thinks the oven is colder than it really is because it's getting intermittent readings. So it overshoots the temp you wanted.
The thermostat in older models gets sticky. Mechanical parts wear out. They don't cycle on and off like they should. Your oven just keeps getting hotter and hotter. That’s not good for that delicate pastry recipe.
Schedule appliance repair service whenever you run into heating problems with your Amana oven.
The Door Won't Close Right
Oven doors take abuse over their life. Slammed shut. Kids hanging on them. Heavy roasting pans bumping into them. Eventually they get out of whack.
Hinges wear out or bend. The door doesn't sit flush anymore. Heat escapes around the edges. Your kitchen gets hot while your food doesn't. Sometimes you can adjust the hinges a bit, but usually they need replacement when they get bad.
Door springs weaken too. The door might drop suddenly instead of closing gently. Those springs help support the weight of the door. When they get weak, the hinges take more stress than they were designed for. Leads to more problems down the road.
The gasket around the door gets torn or compressed. Doesn't make a good seal anymore. Heat leaks out. Makes the oven work harder and your food take longer to cook. Gaskets can be replaced, but getting the old adhesive off is a pain in the neck.
Self-Cleaning Problems
Self-cleaning sounds great on paper. In practice, it's where a lot of problems start. Amanas are no exception.

The extreme heat during cleaning kills electronic parts. Control boards, switches, and wiring take a beating when the oven gets that hot. Sometimes they work fine for years, then you run self-clean once and something dies. That’s just the way it goes.
Door locks stick after cleaning. The lock is supposed to release when the oven cools down. Sometimes the mechanism gets gummed up or bent and the door stays locked. Not ideal when your oven is suddenly a vault you can't open.
Heating elements give up during the clean cycle. All that extra heat pushes them past their breaking point, especially if they were already getting weak. Many repair guys will tell you to never use self-clean. Just wipe the oven out regular instead.

Burners Acting Up
Cooktop burners have their own sets of problems, different ones for gas and electric models.
Gas burners clog up with food spills. The little holes get blocked and you see uneven flames or yellow tips instead of blue. Poking them clean with a pin helps sometimes, but you’ve got to be careful not to enlarge the holes.
Spark igniters fail or get dirty. You hear them clicking but the burner won't light. Or they don't click at all. Food boils over and gums up the igniter. Clean them with a toothbrush and some alcohol. Beats replacing them.
Electric coils have it rough. Stuff spills on them constantly. They're built to take it, but connections corrode over time. The burner receptacles where they plug in get burned or bent. Sometimes a burner works when you jiggle it just right, but that's a fire hazard waiting to happen.
Strange Noises
Amana ovens make all kinds of weird sounds when they're having trouble. Different noises mean different problems.
Buzzing or humming usually points to something electrical. Relay switches buzz when they're not making good contact. The transformer hums louder than it should when it's going bad. Bad news either way.
Clicking repeatedly, not just when starting up, means a relay or switch is cycling on and off too fast. It could be a bad connection or failing part.
Grinding noises from the convection fan mean the bearings are shot. Or something's come loose and is hitting the fan blade. Shut it off until it's fixed or you'll have a bigger problem.
Booming when a gas oven ignites means gas built up before lighting. The igniter's weak or the gas flow needs adjustment. Not something to ignore - it can get dangerous.
Digital Display Dead
The display screen just dies on some models. It goes completely blank or shows gibberish.

Power glitches kill these displays sometimes. Try resetting the control board. Unplug the oven shut off the house circuit breaker for a few minutes. Restore power and see if the oven works. This simple fix sometimes works.
Ribbon cables work loose. They connect the display to the control board. Heat and time make them brittle or they just vibrate loose. Getting to them means taking apart the control panel. Not difficult but lots of small screws to keep track of.
Water damage happens too. Steam from cooking gets into places it shouldn't. Condensation builds up inside the control panel. Eventually shorts something out. Doesn't help that many kitchens put the oven below the cooktop where all the steam rises past the controls.

When To Call For Service
Some Amana oven issues you can handle yourself. Cleaning burners, replacing light bulbs, maybe even changing the oven gasket if you're handy. Keep your manual handy. Save yourself a service call when it's something simple.
But for anything involving gas, electricity, or major disassembly, that's when calling us makes sense. Our techs have seen every Amana problem there is. Keeping your family safe matters more than saving a few bucks trying to fix a gas valve yourself.
We stock parts for all the common Amana problems. Can usually fix things in one visit. And we guarantee our work. No crossing your fingers hoping you fixed it right.
Give us a call when your Amana needs professional attention. We'll get your kitchen back to normal without the headache. The extreme heat during cleaning kills electronic parts. Control boards, switches, and wiring take a beating when the oven gets that hot. Sometimes they work fine for years, then you run self-clean once and something dies. That’s just the way it goes.
Door locks stick after cleaning. The lock is supposed to release when the oven cools down. Sometimes the mechanism gets gummed up or bent and the door stays locked. Not ideal when your oven is suddenly a vault you can't open.
Heating elements give up during the clean cycle. All that extra heat pushes them past their breaking point, especially if they were already getting weak. Many repair guys will tell you to never use self-clean. Just wipe the oven out regular instead.

Burners Acting Up
Cooktop burners have their own sets of problems, different ones for gas and electric models.
Gas burners clog up with food spills. The little holes get blocked and you see uneven flames or yellow tips instead of blue. Poking them clean with a pin helps sometimes, but you’ve got to be careful not to enlarge the holes.
Spark igniters fail or get dirty. You hear them clicking but the burner won't light. Or they don't click at all. Food boils over and gums up the igniter. Clean them with a toothbrush and some alcohol. Beats replacing them.
Electric coils have it rough. Stuff spills on them constantly. They're built to take it, but connections corrode over time. The burner receptacles where they plug in get burned or bent. Sometimes a burner works when you jiggle it just right, but that's a fire hazard waiting to happen.
Strange Noises
Amana ovens make all kinds of weird sounds when they're having trouble. Different noises mean different problems.
Buzzing or humming usually points to something electrical. Relay switches buzz when they're not making good contact. The transformer hums louder than it should when it's going bad. Bad news either way.
Clicking repeatedly, not just when starting up, means a relay or switch is cycling on and off too fast. It could be a bad connection or failing part.
Grinding noises from the convection fan mean the bearings are shot. Or something's come loose and is hitting the fan blade. Shut it off until it's fixed or you'll have a bigger problem.
Booming when a gas oven ignites means gas built up before lighting. The igniter's weak or the gas flow needs adjustment. Not something to ignore - it can get dangerous.
Digital Display Dead
The display screen just dies on some models. It goes completely blank or shows gibberish.

Power glitches kill these displays sometimes. Try resetting the control board. Unplug the oven shut off the house circuit breaker for a few minutes. Restore power and see if the oven works. This simple fix sometimes works.
Ribbon cables work loose. They connect the display to the control board. Heat and time make them brittle or they just vibrate loose. Getting to them means taking apart the control panel. Not difficult but lots of small screws to keep track of.
Water damage happens too. Steam from cooking gets into places it shouldn't. Condensation builds up inside the control panel. Eventually shorts something out. Doesn't help that many kitchens put the oven below the cooktop where all the steam rises past the controls.

When To Call For Service
Some Amana oven issues you can handle yourself. Cleaning burners, replacing light bulbs, maybe even changing the oven gasket if you're handy. Keep your manual handy. Save yourself a service call when it's something simple.
But for anything involving gas, electricity, or major disassembly, that's when calling us makes sense. Our techs have seen every Amana problem there is. Keeping your family safe matters more than saving a few bucks trying to fix a gas valve yourself.
We stock parts for all the common Amana problems. Can usually fix things in one visit. And we guarantee our work. No crossing your fingers hoping you fixed it right.
Give us a call when your Amana needs professional attention. We'll get your kitchen back to normal without the headache. No more takeout needed.

Amana Oven Repair GuideRegardless of the type of Amana oven you have, the appliance repair experts at Sears Home Services can perform quality repairs for problems big or small. A service call involves diagnosing the appliance's malfunction and making repairs quickly. A repair technician can also recommend routine maintenance to extend your oven's life.
We work on Amana ovens all the time. While mostly a reliable appliance, your oven can eventually break at any time.
After thousands of service visits, we've identified several issues that tend to frustrate homeowners most.
Oven Not Heating Up
Turn the oven on and wait. And wait. And nothing happens. No heat. This happens with Amanas more than you'd think. It’s usually caused by a few common culprits.

The igniter gets weak over time. It's supposed to glow hot enough to open the gas valve, but after a few years they just can't get hot enough anymore. You might see it glowing orange but the burner never lights. Or sometimes it takes forever to light, way longer than it should. Igniters aren't cheap parts, but they're the most common thing to fail on gas Amana ovens.
Electric models have different problems. The bake element might be burned out. Look for holes or blisters in the element, or spots where it's clearly broken. They don't always show obvious damage though. Sometimes they look fine but are dead inside. Like some people I've worked with over the years.
Broken wires happen too. The oven gets hot, then cold, over and over for years. Wires get brittle. Connections work loose. One bad connection anywhere in the circuit and the whole oven won't heat.

Control Board Problems
Control boards go bad in the newer electronic models. Everything looks normal on the display, but no command ever reaches the heating elements. These boards hate power surges. One good lightning storm and they're fried. Replacing them isn't a simple job. They cost a fair bit too, sometimes almost half what a new oven would run you.
Schedule wall oven repair when the control won’t work on your Amana oven.
Temperature All Wrong
We had a customer last month, said his cookies always burned even when he set the temperature real low. It turns out his Amana oven was running about 75 degrees hotter than what the control was set to. Temperature issues are frustrating.
The temperature sensor goes out of calibration. It's just a little probe sticking into the back of the oven cavity. It gets covered in grease and gunk over time. Sometimes it gets bent or damaged when people clean. If it's not in the right position or damaged, you get bad readings.
Loose connections to the sensor cause temperature swings too. The computer thinks the oven is colder than it really is because it's getting intermittent readings. So it overshoots the temp you wanted.
The thermostat in older models gets sticky. Mechanical parts wear out. They don't cycle on and off like they should. Your oven just keeps getting hotter and hotter. That’s not good for that delicate pastry recipe.
Schedule appliance repair service whenever you run into heating problems with your Amana oven.
The Door Won't Close Right
Oven doors take abuse over their life. Slammed shut. Kids hanging on them. Heavy roasting pans bumping into them. Eventually they get out of whack.
Hinges wear out or bend. The door doesn't sit flush anymore. Heat escapes around the edges. Your kitchen gets hot while your food doesn't. Sometimes you can adjust the hinges a bit, but usually they need replacement when they get bad.
Door springs weaken too. The door might drop suddenly instead of closing gently. Those springs help support the weight of the door. When they get weak, the hinges take more stress than they were designed for. Leads to more problems down the road.
The gasket around the door gets torn or compressed. Doesn't make a good seal anymore. Heat leaks out. Makes the oven work harder and your food take longer to cook. Gaskets can be replaced, but getting the old adhesive off is a pain in the neck.

full_content.content: Amana ovens make all kinds of weird sounds when they're having trouble. Different noises mean different problems.
full_content.attributes: {"class":"text-gray-500 text-sm md:text-md font-normal leading-6 font-montserrat text-left my-2"}

full_content.content: Buzzing or humming usually points to something electrical. Relay switches buzz when they're not making good contact. The transformer hums louder than it should when it's going bad. Bad news either way.
full_content.attributes: {"class":"text-gray-500 text-sm md:text-md font-normal leading-6 font-montserrat text-left my-2"}

full_content.content: Clicking repeatedly, not just when starting up, means a relay or switch is cycling on and off too fast. It could be a bad connection or failing part.
full_content.attributes: {"class":"text-gray-500 text-sm md:text-md font-normal leading-6 font-montserrat text-left my-2"}

full_content.content: Grinding noises from the convection fan mean the bearings are shot. Or something's come loose and is hitting the fan blade. Shut it off until it's fixed or you'll have a bigger problem.
full_content.attributes: {"class":"text-gray-500 text-sm md:text-md font-normal leading-6 font-montserrat text-left my-2"}

full_content.content: Booming when a gas oven ignites means gas built up before lighting. The igniter's weak or the gas flow needs adjustment. Not something to ignore - it can get dangerous.
full_content.attributes: {"class":"text-gray-500 text-sm md:text-md font-normal leading-6 font-montserrat text-left my-2"}
{"node":"[object Object]","class":"text-left text-4xl my-2 leading-9 text-blue-300 font-oswald lg:text-4xl-plus font-normal"}

full_content.content: The display screen just dies on some models. It goes completely blank or shows gibberish.
full_content.attributes: {"class":"text-gray-500 text-sm md:text-md font-normal leading-6 font-montserrat text-left my-2"}

full_content.content:
Power glitches kill these displays sometimes. Try resetting the control board. Unplug the oven shut off the house circuit breaker for a few minutes. Restore power and see if the oven works. This simple fix sometimes works.
Ribbon cables work loose. They connect the display to the control board. Heat and time make them brittle or they just vibrate loose. Getting to them means taking apart the control panel. Not difficult but lots of small screws to keep track of.
Water damage happens too. Steam from cooking gets into places it shouldn't. Condensation builds up inside the control panel. Eventually shorts something out. Doesn't help that many kitchens put the oven below the cooktop where all the steam rises past the controls.
full_content.attributes: {"class":"list-disc font-normal text-left text-gray-500 text-md leading-6 pl-12 sm:pl-14","node":"[object Object]"}

full_content.content: Some Amana oven issues you can handle yourself. Cleaning burners, replacing light bulbs, maybe even changing the oven gasket if you're handy. Keep your manual handy. Save yourself a service call when it's something simple.
full_content.attributes: {"class":"text-gray-500 text-sm md:text-md font-normal leading-6 font-montserrat text-left my-2"}

full_content.content: But for anything involving gas, electricity, or major disassembly, that's when calling us makes sense. Our techs have seen every Amana problem there is. Keeping your family safe matters more than saving a few bucks trying to fix a gas valve yourself.
full_content.attributes: {"class":"text-gray-500 text-sm md:text-md font-normal leading-6 font-montserrat text-left my-2"}

full_content.content: We stock parts for all the common Amana problems. Can usually fix things in one visit. And we guarantee our work. No crossing your fingers hoping you fixed it right.
full_content.attributes: {"class":"text-gray-500 text-sm md:text-md font-normal leading-6 font-montserrat text-left my-2"}

full_content.content: Give us a call when your Amana needs professional attention. We'll get your kitchen back to normal without the headache. No more takeout needed.
full_content.attributes: {"class":"text-gray-500 text-sm md:text-md font-normal leading-6 font-montserrat text-left my-2"}

full_content.content: Glossary TermsWhat is a Convection Oven?A convection oven is a kitchen appliance that uses a fan to circulate hot air around food, cooking it more evenly and often more quickly than a traditional oven.What is a Thermocouple?A thermocouple is a sensor used for measuring temperature, consisting of two different metal wires joined at one end, which generate a voltage proportional to temperature changes.What is an Oven Bag?An oven bag is a heat-resistant, nylon or polyester bag designed for cooking a wide variety of foods in the oven, ensuring moist and flavorful meals by trapping moisture and flavor inside.What is an Oven Rack?An oven rack is a removable shelving unit inside an oven that holds cookware, allowing air to circulate around the food for even cooking and baking.

self.__next_f.push([1,"Regardless of the type of Amana oven you have, the [appliance repair](/repair) experts at Sears Home Services can perform quality repairs for problems big or small. A service call involves diagnosing the appliance's malfunction and making repairs quickly. A repair technician can also recommend routine maintenance to extend your oven's life.

We work on Amana ovens all the time. While mostly a reliable appliance, your oven can eventually break at any time.

After thousands of service visits, we've identified several issues that tend to frustrate homeowners most.

## Oven Not Heating Up 

Turn the oven on and wait. And wait. And nothing happens. No heat. This happens with Amanas more than you'd think. It’s usually caused by a few common culprits. 

 * The igniter gets weak over time. It's supposed to glow hot enough to open the gas valve, but after a few years they just can't get hot enough anymore. You might see it glowing orange but the burner never lights. Or sometimes it takes forever to light, way longer than it should. Igniters aren't cheap parts, but they're the most common thing to fail on gas Amana ovens. 
* Electric models have different problems. The bake element might be burned out. Look for holes or blisters in the element, or spots where it's clearly broken. They don't always show obvious damage though. Sometimes they look fine but are dead inside. Like some people I've worked with over the years. 
* Broken wires happen too. The oven gets hot, then cold, over and over for years. Wires get brittle. Connections work loose. One bad connection anywhere in the circuit and the whole oven won't heat. 

## Control Board Problems 

Control boards go bad in the newer electronic models. Everything looks normal on the display, but no command ever reaches the heating elements. These boards hate power surges. One good lightning storm and they're fried. Replacing them isn't a simple job. They cost a fair bit too, sometimes almost half what a new oven would run you. 

Schedule [wall oven repair](/repair/oven-repair-service) when the control won’t work on your Amana oven.

## Temperature All Wrong 

We had a customer last month, said his cookies always burned even when he set the temperature real low. It turns out his Amana oven was running about 75 degrees hotter than what the control was set to. Temperature issues are frustrating. 

The temperature sensor goes out of calibration. It's just a little probe sticking into the back of the oven cavity. It gets covered in grease and gunk over time. Sometimes it gets bent or damaged when people clean. If it's not in the right position or damaged, you get bad readings. 

Loose connections to the sensor cause temperature swings too. The computer thinks the oven is colder than it really is because it's getting intermittent readings. So it overshoots the temp you wanted. 

The thermostat in older models gets sticky. Mechanical parts wear out. They don't cycle on and off like they should. Your oven just keeps getting hotter and hotter. That’s not good for that delicate pastry recipe. 

Schedule [appliance repair](/repair) service whenever you run into heating problems with your Amana oven.

## The Door Won't Close Right 

Oven doors take abuse over their life. Slammed shut. Kids hanging on them. Heavy roasting pans bumping into them. Eventually they get out of whack. 

Hinges wear out or bend. The door doesn't sit flush anymore. Heat escapes around the edges. Your kitchen gets hot while your food doesn't. Sometimes you can adjust the hinges a bit, but usually they need replacement when they get bad. 

Door springs weaken too. The door might drop suddenly instead of closing gently. Those springs help support the weight of the door. When they get weak, the hinges take more stress than they were designed for. Leads to more problems down the road. 

The gasket around the door gets torn or compressed. Doesn't make a good seal anymore. Heat leaks out. Makes the oven work harder and your food take longer to cook. Gaskets can be replaced, but getting the old adhesive off is a pain in the neck. 

## Self-Cleaning Problems 

Self-cleaning sounds great on paper. In practice, it's where a lot of problems start. Amanas are no exception. 

* The extreme heat during cleaning kills electronic parts. Control boards, switches, and wiring take a beating when the oven gets that hot. Sometimes they work fine for years, then you run self-clean once and something dies. That’s just the way it goes. 
* Door locks stick after cleaning. The lock is supposed to release when the oven cools down. Sometimes the mechanism gets gummed up or bent and the door stays locked. Not ideal when your oven is suddenly a vault you can't open. 
* Heating elements give up during the clean cycle. All that extra heat pushes them past their breaking point, especially if they were already getting weak. Many repair guys will tell you to never use self-clean. Just wipe the oven out regular instead. 

## Burners Acting Up 

Cooktop burners have their own sets of problems, different ones for gas and electric models. 

Gas burners clog up with food spills. The little holes get blocked and you see uneven flames or yellow tips instead of blue. Poking them clean with a pin helps sometimes, but you’ve got to be careful not to enlarge the holes. 

Spark igniters fail or get dirty. You hear them clicking but the burner won't light. Or they don't click at all. Food boils over and gums up the igniter. Clean them with a toothbrush and some alcohol. Beats replacing them. 

Electric coils have it rough. Stuff spills on them constantly. They're built to take it, but connections corrode over time. The burner receptacles where they plug in get burned or bent. Sometimes a burner works when you jiggle it just right, but that's a fire hazard waiting to happen. 

## Strange Noises 

Amana ovens make all kinds of weird sounds when they're having trouble. Different noises mean different problems. 

Buzzing or humming usually points to something electrical. Relay switches buzz when they're not making good contact. The transformer hums louder than it should when it's going bad. Bad news either way. 

Clicking repeatedly, not just when starting up, means a relay or switch is cycling on and off too fast. It could be a bad connection or failing part. 

Grinding noises from the convection fan mean the bearings are shot. Or something's come loose and is hitting the fan blade. Shut it off until it's fixed or you'll have a bigger problem. 

Booming when a gas oven ignites means gas built up before lighting. The igniter's weak or the gas flow needs adjustment. Not something to ignore - it can get dangerous. 

## Digital Display Dead 

The display screen just dies on some models. It goes completely blank or shows gibberish. 

* Power glitches kill these displays sometimes. Try resetting the control board. Unplug the oven shut off the house circuit breaker for a few minutes. Restore power and see if the oven works. This simple fix sometimes works. 
* Ribbon cables work loose. They connect the display to the control board. Heat and time make them brittle or they just vibrate loose. Getting to them means taking apart the control panel. Not difficult but lots of small screws to keep track of. 
* Water damage happens too. Steam from cooking gets into places it shouldn't. Condensation builds up inside the control panel. Eventually shorts something out. Doesn't help that many kitchens put the oven below the cooktop where all the steam rises past the controls. 

## When To Call For Service 

Some Amana oven issues you can handle yourself. Cleaning burners, replacing light bulbs, maybe even changing the oven gasket if you're handy. Keep your manual handy. Save yourself a service call when it's something simple. 

But for anything involving gas, electricity, or major disassembly, that's when calling us makes sense. Our techs have seen every Amana problem there is. Keeping your family safe matters more than saving a few bucks trying to fix a gas valve yourself. 

We stock parts for all the common Amana problems. Can usually fix things in one visit. And we guarantee our work. No crossing your fingers hoping you fixed it right. 

Give us a call when your Amana needs professional attention. We'll get your kitchen back to normal without the headache. No more takeout needed.
"])

self.__next_f.push([1,"## Techniques to Accelerate Oven Preheating

Getting your oven hot quickly isn’t just about saving time—it’s also about making sure your food cooks evenly from the start. These smart ways can help speed up the oven preheating process. By using these strategies, you can get your oven ready faster, ensuring your dishes turn out just right.

### Using the Broiler

The broiler is a great tool for quickly boosting your oven’s temperature. Just be careful to adjust it properly to avoid any mishaps.

- Turn on the broiler for a few minutes at the start.
- Watch your oven closely to avoid letting it get too hot.
- Switch back to regular baking before you put your food in.

### Optimizing Oven Settings

If you have a modern oven, you might have some built-in settings that can make preheating faster. These are definitely worth a try.

- Check if your oven has a 'Rapid Preheat' setting and how to activate it.
- Engage the rapid preheat to speed things up.
- Keep your oven firmware up to date for the best performance.

### Incorporating Heat-Retaining Accessories

Certain accessories can help your oven hold and distribute heat better, which can cut down on preheating time.

- Try baking stones or cast-iron skillets: These can retain a lot of heat and help stabilize your oven’s temperature.
- Place these accessories in while preheating.
- Remember that these can make your oven hotter than usual, so you might need to shorten cooking times slightly.

---

## Ensuring Correct Preheating

Preheating your oven the right way provides the best cooking results. This goes beyond just turning it on a few minutes before baking; it involves following specific best practices to ensure your oven is ideally prepped and ready. Here’s a breakdown of essential steps to follow to preheat your oven properly.

### Following Recommended Preheating Times

It's tempting to rush the preheating process, especially when you're short on time, but sticking to recommended times is crucial for well-cooked meals.

- Resist shortcuts, even if you're in a hurry, and give your oven the full time to heat up as specified.
- Refer to your oven's manual for the precise preheating times.
- Use a timer to remind you when the oven has reached the right temperature.

### Keeping the Oven Unobstructed

An empty oven is the best condition for effective preheating. Removing clutter or unnecessary racks can help heat circulate better.

- Remove any pans, pizza stones, or extra racks that aren't needed for your next cooking session.
- If you need specific racks for your dish, place them appropriately before turning the oven on.
- Ensure nothing is blocking the oven's heating elements.

![cleaning-the-oven-for-efficiency](//images.ctfassets.net/e0821f6q5nel/6LO4oqoN1f9r0tuqaO5Eei/72afda41e0c0bc5696041189d0514bc4/cleaning-the-oven-for-efficiency.png)

### Maintaining Oven Cleanliness

A clean oven is more than just a hygienic necessity; it's a performance enhancer, especially when it comes to preheating efficiently.

- Clean your oven regularly to avoid buildup that can absorb heat.
- Quickly wipe down the oven after each use to prevent the accumulation of grease and crumbs.
- Consider a thorough cleaning every few months to keep the oven in optimal condition.

---

## Avoiding Common Preheating Mistakes

Steering clear of typical preheating mistakes can drastically improve how your oven performs and heats up. Avoid frequent missteps by following these strategies to keep your preheating process on point.

### Common Preheating Errors

Mistakes during preheating can easily affect your cooking. Here's how to recognize and correct these errors to keep your oven performing its best.

- Stick to recommended times; resist the urge to cut preheating short, even if you’re running late.
- Allow your oven to fully preheat to ensure your food cooks evenly.

### Preventing Overcrowding

Putting too much in your oven can block airflow and make it hard for your oven to reach the right temperature.

- Only place items essential for your current baking task inside during preheating.
- Ensure that there's ample space around items to allow for effective heat distribution.

### Prioritizing Oven Maintenance

A well-maintained oven is more than just a cleanliness goal; it’s a must for efficient operation and heating.

- Keep your oven free of grease and food debris that can hinder its performance.
- Perform thorough cleanings periodically to maintain optimal heating and efficiency.

---

## Additional Strategies for Efficient Oven Use

Exploring ways to utilize your oven more effectively can transform your cooking routine. These strategies not only improve your oven's performance but also enhance the overall cooking results.

### Optimizing Oven Loading

Properly loading your oven can make a significant difference in how your food cooks by improving heat distribution and efficiency.

Space out food items in the oven to ensure they receive even heat from all sides. Follow the tips in this brief video to properly position oven racks for even baking:

<iframe width="660" height="371" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/r_tcl5NCDjo" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture" allowfullscreen></iframe>

Organize your cooking to minimize the frequency of opening the oven door, which helps maintain a consistent temperature.

### Leveraging Advanced Oven Features

Utilizing the advanced features of your oven can lead to better cooking outcomes and more efficient kitchen operations.

- Activate the convection mode for quicker and more uniform cooking across different dishes.
- Employ built-in timers and temperature probes to keep your cooking precise, which helps in preventing both undercooking and overcooking.

---

By mastering these preheating and oven usage techniques, you ensure that your culinary dishes are consistently excellent and your oven operates at peak efficiency. Regularly applying these tips can transform your everyday cooking into a seamless and successful routine, letting you enjoy perfectly cooked meals every time.

If you find that your oven still isn’t performing up to par despite following these best practices, it might be time to call in the experts. Don’t let a malfunctioning oven disrupt your cooking momentum. [Schedule a repair service with Sears Home Services](/repair) to get your oven back in top shape. Their professional technicians can diagnose and fix any issue, ensuring your oven returns to its optimal performance. Reach out today and continue to enjoy the benefits of efficient and effective oven use.

---
"])

self.__next_f.push([1,"## What Is a Potentiometer?

A potentiometer, often referred to as a "pot," is a three-terminal device that acts as a variable resistor or voltage divider. It consists of:

* __Resistive Element:__ A strip of material (such as carbon or a composite) with a uniform resistance.
* __Sliding Contact (Wiper):__ A movable arm that glides along the resistive element.
* __Terminals:__
     * Two fixed terminals connected to either end of the resistive element.
     * One terminal connected to the wiper, which adjusts the resistance.

By moving the wiper, you can change the resistance or voltage output, making the potentiometer ideal for controlling variables such as temperature or light intensity.

---

## How Does a Potentiometer Work in an Oven?

In ovens, the potentiometer is often integrated into the temperature control knob. Here's how it works:

* When you turn the knob, the potentiometer’s wiper moves along the resistive element, altering the resistance.
* This change in resistance adjusts the voltage supplied to the oven’s control system, which interprets the signal and modulates the heating elements accordingly.
* Set the pointer on the potentiometer knob to the desired temperature scale position that surrounds the knob on the control panel. The control panel in some ovens provides a digital display of the potentiometer temperature setting. 

The potentiometer give you precise control of the oven temperature setting.

---

## Key Benefits of Potentiometers in Ovens

### Precision

Potentiometers enable fine adjustments to the oven’s settings, allowing for exact temperature control—essential for baking and roasting.

### Durability

High-quality potentiometers are robust and can withstand the repetitive motions of everyday use, as well as the heat and vibrations present in an oven's environment.

### Simplicity

Unlike more complex digital controls, potentiometers are straightforward to use and repair, making them cost-effective and reliable.

---

## Potentiometers vs. Digital Controls: Why They Still Matter

With the rise of digital touchscreens and programmable controls, you might wonder why potentiometers are still in use. The answer lies in their simplicity and reliability.

* __Cost-Effectiveness:__ Potentiometers are cheaper to produce and integrate than advanced digital systems.
* __Ease of Repair:__ A faulty potentiometer can often be replaced without the need for complicated and difficult diagnostics.
* __Tactile Preference:__ Many users prefer the analog feel of turning a knob, especially for tasks like baking.

---

## Maintenance Tips for Oven Potentiometers

To keep your oven's potentiometer in good condition, follow these expert tips.

### Maintenance and Cleaning

* __Clean Regularly:__ Dust or grease can accumulate on and around the knob, interfering with smooth operation. Use a soft cloth and mild cleaner to wipe it down. Follow any additional instructions provided in your oven’s user guide to keep the potentiometer clean.
* __ Inspect the Knob:__ Check for cracks, damage, or excessive play in the knob. Replace the knob if it’s loose or damaged.
* __Replace the Potentiometer When Necessary:__ If the potentiometer becomes unresponsive or erratic, schedule [oven repair](/repair/oven-repair-service) service to have a service technician install a new one.
* __Schedule Professional Oven Maintenance:__ To keep your oven and the potentiometer in top shape and working properly, schedule professional [oven maintenance](/maintain) yearly.

### Calibrating or Adjusting the Potentiometer

Over time, the temperature setting on your oven can drift away from the factory setting. When this happens you'll find that your oven consistently bakes or roasts food faster or slower than the time specified in the recipe.

Fortunately, you can recalibrate your oven temperature potentiometer to get it closer to the original accurate setting.

#### First, find the oven’s average temperature

To know how much to adjust the temperature, you’ll need to know how far off your oven’s actual average temperature is from the temperature you set.

*You’ll need an accurate oven thermometer for this task.*

Because the oven temperature rises and falls around the set temperature as the element or burner cycles on and off, you’ll need to record oven thermometer readings several times to accurately determine actual oven temperature. The more readings you take, the more accurate the average you calculate will be ([oven repair](/repair/oven-repair-service) technicians often take at least 5 readings). 

Follow these steps to accurately find the actual oven temperature:

1. Put the oven thermometer on the middle rack and set the oven to 350 degrees. 
2. Let the oven preheat and then wait at least 10 minutes more for the temperature to level out from the preheating temperature spike.
3. Check the oven thermometer reading by looking through the oven window and record the temperature on a sheet of paper.
4. Wait 10 minutes and record another oven thermometer reading. Continue taking several more readings every 10 minutes.
5. After recording the actual temperature readings from the oven thermometer, add the readings and divide by the number of readings you took to determine the actual oven temperature.

#### Set the temperature offset to make up for the difference

The difference between 350 degrees F and the average temperature you measured is the offset you'll use to recalibrate the oven potentiometer. 

For example, if the average was 330 degrees F, the offset is +20 degrees; if the average was 380 degrees F, the offset is -30 degrees.

You can adjust most oven potentiometers by about 35 degrees in either direction. If the average temperature is off by more than 35 degrees, you may need to replace the potentiometer.

Here are instructions for adjusting the potentiometer in common types of ovens. The exact steps vary by manufacturer, so check your owner's manual for instructions for your model.

1. Pull off the temperature control knob. 
2. On the back of the control knob you’ll find small adjustment screws and a pointer in a track. The back of the knob may be labeled Cooler at one end and Hotter at the other.
3. Loosen the screws just enough that you can move the pointer.
4. Move the pointer toward Cooler if the oven overcooks or Hotter if it undercooks. Each audible click adjusts set temperature about 10 degrees.
5. Tighten the screw and replace the knob.

Here’s an image to illustrate the temperature adjustment:

![how-to-calibrate-a-potentiometer](//images.ctfassets.net/e0821f6q5nel/1mrbDZk9lhP4ClSlaY9h4a/adeef9c09826ef50594498346ab5c35d/calibrating-an-oven-potentiometer.png)

Repeat the process for checking the actual average temperature. Continue adjusting the potentiometer until actual average oven temperature matches the set temperature on the potentiometer.

If you’re unable to calibrate the potentiometer on your own, schedule [appliance repair](/repair) service and we’ll send a Sears Home Services technician to your home to adjust the temperature or replace the potentiometer for you.

Understanding how a potentiometer works and how to adjust it when necessary can help your baked goods to turn out perfect every time.

---

At Sears Home Services, we’re always standing by to help you get the most out of your oven and all of your home appliances. Trust us for all of your home maintenance and repair needs.

Potentiometers adjust stove and oven temperatures by regulating electrical signals. Understanding these controls can help you catch signs of wear—like unresponsive knobs or inconsistent heating. If temperature settings become erratic, [oven repair service](https://www.searshomeservices.com/repair/oven-repair-service) may be the next step. Timely intervention can prevent bigger electronic failures down the line.

---
"])

self.__next_f.push([1,"## Understanding the Basics of Convection Ovens

Convection ovens have gained a reputation for their efficient cooking and consistent results, but understanding how they work can help you get even more out of this popular kitchen appliance. These ovens use advanced technology to improve heat distribution, making them ideal for a wide variety of cooking tasks.

### How Convection Ovens Work

At the heart of a convection oven are three main components: the heating element, a fan, and an exhaust system. Together, they create an environment where food cooks more evenly and efficiently. Here’s how it all comes together:

- **Heating Element**: Located at the bottom or top of the oven, the heating element generates the high temperatures needed for cooking.
- **Fan**: Positioned at the back of the oven, the fan continuously circulates the heated air, spreading it evenly throughout the oven cavity. This airflow eliminates hot and cold spots, so every part of your dish cooks uniformly.
- **Exhaust System**: This system helps remove excess moisture and maintains the right humidity levels, which improves browning and crisping.

By keeping the temperature consistent and circulating hot air around the food, convection ovens deliver faster and more reliable results. This technology is particularly useful for baking cookies, roasting meats, and achieving a perfectly caramelized finish on vegetables.

### Key Differences from Conventional Ovens

The main difference between a convection oven and a conventional oven lies in how heat is distributed. Conventional ovens rely on radiant heat that comes from a single source, such as a heating element at the bottom. This setup can lead to uneven cooking, with certain areas of the oven becoming hotter than others. 

Convection ovens, on the other hand, use a fan to actively circulate hot air. This key difference results in more consistent heat distribution, which brings several advantages:
- **Faster Cooking Times**: The constant airflow speeds up the cooking process, often allowing you to reduce cooking times by up to 25%.
- **Even Heat Distribution**: With hot air continuously moving, there’s no need to worry about rotating pans or dealing with undercooked spots.
- **Lower Cooking Temperatures**: The efficiency of heat transfer means you can often use a lower temperature setting, saving energy without sacrificing results.

These differences make convection ovens a valuable tool for home cooks and professional chefs alike, providing reliability and precision in the kitchen.

![How does a convection oven work_convection oven](//images.ctfassets.net/e0821f6q5nel/1Ie5DEM9yJ8jwqtAsaVZoR/0807410cfdd331a19bd2b585360e9b53/How_does_a_convection_oven_work_convection_oven.jpg)

## Advantages of Using a Convection Oven

Convection ovens are highly valued for their impressive cooking performance and efficiency. They provide a range of benefits that make them a favorite among home cooks and culinary professionals alike.

### Faster and Even Cooking

One of the biggest advantages of a convection oven is its ability to cook food quickly and evenly. The continuous circulation of hot air through the oven cavity accelerates the cooking process. This constant airflow distributes the heat uniformly, so there are no hot or cold spots. As a result, dishes like roasted meats turn out perfectly browned on the outside and juicy on the inside, while baked goods achieve a beautiful golden finish.

This faster cooking process not only saves time but also improves the texture and appearance of your meals. Whether you’re roasting a whole chicken or baking a delicate soufflé, the consistent heat provided by a convection oven provides reliable and even results.

### Energy Efficiency

Energy savings is a major benefit of convection ovens. Because the circulating hot air speeds up cooking, you can often reduce both the temperature setting and the cooking time. For example, many recipes let you lower the temperature by about 25 degrees Fahrenheit, which translates to less energy consumption.

Shorter cooking times mean that the oven doesn’t need to work as hard or stay on as long, which can lead to noticeable savings on energy bills over time. Using a convection oven is an efficient choice that benefits both your kitchen routine and your wallet.

### Versatility

Another standout feature of convection ovens is their versatility. These ovens can handle multiple dishes at once without the worry of flavors transferring. Thanks to the even heat distribution, you can bake cookies on one rack while roasting vegetables on another, and each dish will cook to perfection. The fan keeps aromas and flavors from mingling, which is especially useful when preparing meals for large gatherings or experimenting with different recipes.

This flexibility lets you maximize oven space and prepare multiple dishes simultaneously, making meal preparation more efficient and stress-free. Whether you’re hosting a dinner party or simply cooking for the family, a convection oven can help streamline your time in the kitchen.

## Tips for Using a Convection Oven Effectively

Getting the best results from your convection oven requires a few adjustments and thoughtful choices. Here are some practical tips for perfectly cooked meals every time.

### Choosing the Right Bakeware and Cookware

The type of bakeware and cookware you use greatly impacts the performance of your convection oven. For optimal airflow and even cooking, shallow, rimmed pans or baking sheets are your best options. These let the hot air circulate more efficiently around the food, helping to achieve that ideal crispy or golden finish.

On the other hand, deep pans or covered dishes can disrupt the airflow and result in uneven cooking. Avoid using bakeware that blocks air circulation, as it can lead to undercooked centers or overcooked edges. Opt for lightweight metal or glass dishes that work well with the convection oven’s heat distribution.

### Adapting Recipes for Convection Cooking

Convection ovens often require slight adjustments to standard recipes. Because these ovens cook food faster and at a more even temperature, you’ll usually need to lower the temperature by about 25 degrees Fahrenheit. A 25% reduction in cooking times may be necessary, so it’s important to keep a close eye on your dishes as they cook. 

If you’re trying a new recipe, start checking for doneness a few minutes earlier than you would in a conventional oven. Experiment with small adjustments to find what works best for your oven and your favorite dishes. With a bit of practice, you’ll be able to master any recipe with ease.

### Common Mistakes to Avoid

Using a convection oven effectively means avoiding some common pitfalls. One of the biggest mistakes is overcrowding the oven. Proper air circulation is a must for even cooking, so leave enough space between pans for the hot air to flow freely. If you pack the oven too tightly, you risk uneven results.

Preheating is also important with a convection oven. Starting with a hot oven provides consistent temperatures throughout the cooking process. Avoid using aluminum foil or covering dishes with lids. These can block the airflow, preventing your food from cooking evenly or getting the crisp texture that convection ovens are known for.

By understanding these tips and making small adjustments, you can take full advantage of everything your convection oven has to offer.

![How does a convection oven work_inside with cookies](//images.ctfassets.net/e0821f6q5nel/7Idldo0uaUaE3thECi2OR4/b5b3cc7a55bbbe0e529cf18915ab6ab0/How_does_a_convection_oven_work_inside_with_cookies.jpg)

## Caring for a Convection Oven

Consistent performance and long-lasting use of your convection oven starts with keeping it in shape. With the right maintenance and troubleshooting know-how, you can make certain it operates efficiently and safely.

### Maintenance Tips

Regular cleaning and proper care make a difference in how well your convection oven performs. Start by wiping down the interior after each use to remove food residues and spills. Use a mild dish soap mixed with warm water and a soft cloth to clean the surfaces, avoiding abrasive cleaners or scrubbing pads that could damage the finish.

Oven racks and trays should also be cleaned regularly. Soak them in warm, soapy water to loosen any grease or stuck-on food, then scrub gently and rinse thoroughly. Once dry, place them back in the oven. To maximize your oven's lifespan, consider scheduling [yearly professional maintenance](/maintain) to address deeper cleanings and check for any underlying issues.

### Troubleshooting Common Issues

Even with proper care, convection ovens may experience occasional problems. If you notice uneven heating, check to make sure that nothing is blocking the airflow inside the oven. You can also verify that the temperature settings are accurate by using an oven thermometer and recalibrating as needed.

Strange noises could indicate loose or damaged parts, so inspect the fan and other components carefully. If tightening or realigning parts doesn’t resolve the issue, it may require professional attention. Keeping a close eye on your oven's performance will help you catch and address minor problems before they worsen.

### When to Call a Professional

While some issues can be handled on your own, others require expert intervention. If your convection oven struggles with persistent heating problems, displays error codes, or produces unusual smells or smoke, it’s time to seek help. These could be signs of electrical faults or other serious concerns. For reliable and safe repairs, turn to professional [oven repair](/repair/oven-repair-service) services.

Taking care of your convection oven means you’ll enjoy delicious, evenly cooked meals for years to come. By following regular cleaning routines and scheduling [professional maintenance](/maintain) once a year, you can keep your oven running smoothly. And when issues arise that require expert help, professional [oven repair](/repair/oven-repair-service) services are just a call away to get your appliance back on track.

Convection ovens circulate hot air via fans, reducing baking times and promoting even browning. If those fans break or your food still comes out patchy, mechanical failures may be at fault. Don’t overlook [gas repair near me](https://www.searshomeservices.com/repair/oven-repair-service) or electric repair services if you spot irregular fan speeds. Keeping the convection system in top shape means faster and more reliable cooking results.
"])

self.__next_f.push([1,"## 1. Should I opt for a freestanding or built-in oven?

As a homeowner in the market for a new oven, one of the first decisions you'll need to make is whether you prefer a freestanding oven or a built-in oven. Both options have their own unique set of advantages and disadvantages, so it's important to weigh these against your personal needs and preferences.

Freestanding ovens are independent units that can be situated anywhere in your kitchen. They tend to be less expensive and easier to install as they don't require any alterations to your kitchen cabinetry. Freestanding ovens are versatile, available in a range of sizes, styles, and fuel types, allowing you to pick the one that best matches your cooking requirements.

However, freestanding ovens do have some limitations. They often have less oven capacity compared to built-in ovens, which can be a drawback if you frequently cook large meals or entertain guests. Additionally, the design of freestanding ovens may not blend seamlessly with your kitchen decor, especially if you have a specific aesthetic in mind.

Built-in ovens, on the other hand, are designed to be installed directly into your kitchen cabinetry. They offer a sleek and integrated look that effortlessly meshes with your kitchen design. Built-in ovens often boast larger oven capacities, making them ideal for those who regularly cook for larger groups.

However, the installation of built-in ovens can be more intricate and may necessitate professional assistance. They are generally more costly than freestanding ovens. Also, should you decide to move or remodel your kitchen in the future, built-in ovens may not be as easily transferrable or adaptable as freestanding ovens.

When choosing between freestanding and built-in ovens, consider aspects such as your cooking needs, kitchen layout, budget, and desired aesthetic. Ultimately, the decision boils down to personal preference and what will work best for your specific situation.

## 2. Should I choose a gas or electric oven?

Another key decision you'll need to make when buying a new oven is whether to opt for a gas or electric model. Here are some factors to consider when making this choice.

* __Gas vs. Electric Ovens:__ Gas and electric ovens each have their own unique features. Gas ovens provide immediate heat and precise temperature control, making them a favorite among professional chefs or anyone who enjoys baking. Electric ovens, on the other hand, offer even heat distribution and consistent cooking results, making them ideal for day-to-day cooking needs.
* __Energy Efficiency and Cost:__ Gas ovens are generally more energy-efficient than electric ovens. This means that you'll save money on your energy bills over time. However, electric ovens are often cheaper to purchase upfront. It's important to balance the initial cost against the long-term energy savings to determine which option is best for your budget.
* __Choosing the Right Fuel Type for Your Cooking Needs:__ Consider your cooking habits and preferences. If you enjoy baking delicate pastries or bread, a gas oven with its precise temperature control may be the better choice. Conversely, if you frequently cook on the stovetop and prefer a seamless aesthetic in your kitchen, an electric oven with a smooth cooktop may be more suitable.

At Sears, [we offer a wide range of gas and electric ovens](https://www.sears.com/upgrade) to cater to every cooking style and budget. Our knowledgeable team is ready to help you find the perfect oven that meets your needs and preferences. 

## 3. What size oven do I need?

When shopping for a new oven, it's vital to consider the size. You want to ensure that the oven you select fits seamlessly into your kitchen space. Here are some key factors to consider:

* __Measuring Your Space:__ Before you begin browsing for a new oven, it's crucial to accurately measure your kitchen space. Take into account the width, depth, and height of the area where you plan to install the oven. This will help you ascertain the maximum size of oven that will comfortably fit in your kitchen.
* __Single vs. Double Ovens:__ You'll also need to decide whether you prefer a single oven or a double oven. Single ovens are ideal for smaller kitchens or for those who don't cook frequently. Conversely, if you love to entertain or have a large family, a double oven can offer more cooking space and flexibility.
* __Oven Capacity:__ The capacity of an oven refers to the amount of cooking space available. Consider the size of your family, your cooking habits, and the types of dishes you typically prepare. If you regularly cook large meals or bake multiple dishes simultaneously, a larger capacity oven may be more suitable for your needs.

Sears offers a wide selection of ovens in various sizes and capacities to meet your specific requirements. Our expert team can guide you to the perfect oven that fits seamlessly into your kitchen. When you choose Sears, you can rest assured that you're investing in a high-quality appliance that will enhance your cooking experience.

## 4. Are digital controls better than traditional knobs?

When selecting a new oven, one of the choices you'll need to make is whether to opt for digital controls or traditional knob controls. Both options have their advantages, so it's vital to consider your personal preferences and cooking style.

### Advantages of Digital Controls

* __Precision:__ Digital controls allow you to set the exact temperature and cooking time, ensuring consistent results every time. This can be particularly beneficial for baking delicate pastries or roasting meats.
* __Convenience:__ Digital controls enable you to easily program your oven to start and stop cooking at specific times. This means you can arrive home to a meal that's ready and waiting for you.
* __Advanced Features:__ Many ovens with digital controls offer additional features like convection cooking, steam settings, and pre-programmed recipes. These features can help you experiment with new cooking techniques and expand your culinary horizons.
* __Smart connectivity:__ Some ovens with digital controls can connect through your home’s Wi-Fi to your smart phone or tablet so you can remotely monitor and control the oven.

### Benefits of Traditional Knob Controls

* __Simplicity:__ Knob controls are straightforward and intuitive to use. You simply turn the knob to your desired temperature or cooking mode, making them ideal for those who prefer a more traditional approach.
* __Durability:__ Knob controls are mechanical, which means they are less likely to malfunction compared to digital controls that rely on electronic components.
* __Cost:__ Ovens with traditional knob controls tend to be more affordable compared to their digital counterparts.

### Choosing the Right Control Type

Ultimately, the decision between digital and knob controls is a matter of personal preference. Consider your cooking habits, lifestyle, and comfort level with technology. If you enjoy exploring advanced features and desire precise control over your cooking, digital controls may be the better choice for you. On the other hand, if simplicity, durability, and cost are your priorities, knob controls might be the better option.

## 5. Which features are most important?

When purchasing a new oven, it's important to consider the features that will enhance your cooking experience and simplify your cooking process. Here are some must-have features to consider:

### Features to Enhance Your Cooking Experience

* __Convection Cooking:__ Seek out an oven with convection capabilities, which evenly circulates hot air for faster and more even cooking. This feature is particularly beneficial for baking and roasting.
* __Variable Broil:__ Having the ability to adjust the broiling temperature allows you to achieve perfect browning and caramelization on a variety of dishes.
* __Self-Cleaning:__ Consider a self-cleaning oven to simplify maintenance. This feature saves you time and effort by eliminating the need for manual scrubbing.

### Features to Simplify Your Cooking Process

* __Programmable Settings:__ Seek an oven with programmable settings that allow you to set the cooking time and temperature in advance. This feature is beneficial for busy individuals who desire a hot and ready meal upon arriving home.
* __Dual Fuel:__ If you prefer the precision of gas cooking on the stovetop but want the consistency of electric baking, consider a dual fuel oven. This type of oven combines the best of both worlds.

### Prioritizing Features Based on Your Specific Needs

Consider your cooking habits and priorities when deciding on features. For instance, if you frequently bake, convection cooking and precise temperature control may be high on your list. Conversely, if you often cook large meals, a spacious oven with multiple racks and a warming drawer might be more important.

Also, remember to consider your budget when selecting an oven. While it's great to have all the latest features, it's important to choose those that align with your needs and preferences.

Purchasing an oven can be overwhelming with so many designs and features available. This piece walks you through five key considerations, such as fuel type, capacity, and long-term maintenance. Yet, sometimes a simple repair is more cost-effective. Before committing to a new model, explore [stove repair](https://www.searshomeservices.com/repair/oven-repair-service) to see if existing issues can be resolved without the hefty price tag of replacement.
